column3: This is a robust Pinot Noir, marked by excessive alcohol that gives it a peppery burn throughout. Beyond that, it's dry and silky, with flavors of very ripe cherry, red currant and Dr. Pepper.

column2: Mara 2009 Laughlin Road Ranch Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: This is a robust Pinot Noir, marked by excessive alcohol that gives it a peppery burn throughout. Beyond that, it's dry and silky, with flavors of very ripe cherry, red currant and Dr. Pepper.

column2: Healdsburg Ranches 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
column3: Good price for a nice, dry Cabernet with so much fruit. It's forward in ripe blackberry, blueberry and cherry jam flavors, with a rich coat of smoky oak.

column2: Cosentino 2007 The Zin Zinfandel (Lodi)
column3: Lusty and strong, this is Lodi Zinfandel at its most classic. It's a big, thick, softly ripe wine that floods the mouth with exuberant flavors of blackberry jam, chocolate, red and black currants and peppery spices. Easy to like. Drink now.

column2: Pedroncelli 2007 Mother Clone Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: Here's a young, lusty, grapey Zinfandel that really gets the tastebuds watering. Crisp acidity stimulates the palate, while rich, dry flavors reward it with an array of briary blackberries, cherries, chocolate, tobacco and spices. Textbook Dry Creek Zinfandel.

column2: Roessler 2006 Hein Family Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)
column3: Very big, very dry and powerful, a Pinot that explodes with lush cherry jam, red currant, chocolate and spice flavors wrapped into a tannic and frankly acidic young wine. If you pop the cork now, give it a good decant.

column2: Sobon Estate 2006 Rezerve Zinfandel (Amador County)
column3: Here's an exuberant, country-style Zin that's easy to drink with barbecue. It's enormously fruity in blackberries, currants, mulberries and cinnamon-spicy mocha, with firm tannins that need rich meats to unlock. Drink soon.

column2: Ghost Block 2009 Single Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Yountville)
column3: Sweet in blackberry, blueberry marmalade and cassis flavors, this has notable acidity that provides a scouring mouthfeel. It's a bit rustic now, especially with its jagged tannins, but the finish is dry and long. Sometimes these wines mellow and age well, but this one doesn't seem destined to benefit from cellaring.

column2: Steven Kent 2007 Smith Ranch Cabernet Sauvignon (Livermore Valley)
column3: This is a lovely wine to drink now. It's so dry and elegantly constructed, with wonderfully ripe tannins and great integration of oak with the fruit. There's a nice balance of acidity to balance the blackberry, cherry and cola flavors. Drink now, with a brief decant.

column2: Thomas Fogarty 2005 Gist Ranch Estate Merlot (Santa Cruz Mountains)
column3: Bring this down to the cellar and let it sleep for at least 5–6 years. It's super-tannic, giving a hard, angular mouthfeel, even though the blackberry, cherry, currant and cedar flavors are powerful. It just wants to throw some sediment and let that mountain fruit shine.

column2: Rockroom Winemaking Cooperative 2008 Lone Oak Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
column3: There are lush, profound flavors of cherries, red currants, licorice, bacon and sweet smoky sandalwood in this wine, and it has the silky mouthfeel of a fine coastal Pinot. On the debit side is a certain harshness and sharpness of tannins that suggests green seeds.

column2: Occidental Road Cellars 2008 Horseshoe Bend Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: This has plenty of cherry, red licorice, cola and spice flavors that are wrapped into firm tannins. Long on the finish, this is a very good example of a Russian River Valley Pinot Noir.

column2: Williams Selyem 2009 Vista Verde Vineyard Pinot Noir (San Benito County)
column3: A very good, impressively concentrated Pinot Noir, with flashy, ripe cherry, blackberry and currant flavors. It's a little too robust right now, with an almost rustic mouthfeel, but could develop bottle complexity over the years.

column2: Calera 2006 Reed Vineyard Pinot Noir (Mt. Harlan)
column3: Shows a dryness and earthiness that mark Calera's most ageworthy Pinot Noirs. But that doesn't mean it's not good now. It is, with impressive black cherry, licorice, bacon, vanilla and sandalwood flavors, wrapped into a drily crisp, silky texture. Drink through 2012, at least.

column2: Autonom 2007 Law of Proportions Syrah (California)
column3: The components of this wine are all over the place, with blackberry and currant fruit, 100% new oak, brisk tannins and acidity needing to come together for harmony. Whether or not they will is a guess. Right now it's rustic, but dry and complex enough to drink after a good decant.

column2: Kenneth Volk 2008 Merlot (Paso Robles)
column3: Soft, rich and sweet, this is an easy Merlot for drinking now. It has ripe, forward cherry, mocha and oak flavors, with a hint of bacon that suggests pairing with pork-based entrées.

column2: Foxen 2009 Sea Smoke Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
column3: Heavy and rich, as Pinots from this vineyard tend to be. Also exceptionally ripe, with massive cherry marmalade and smoky, sweet oak flavors. Feels young and direct and easy to drink, with a fruity sweetness. Glamorous, but the price seems out of line.

column2: Windbreak 2006 Sarmento Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
column3: A bit tart in acidity, this polished Pinot needs rich beef or lamb to cut through. It's a lovely wine, fully dry and balanced, with rich flavors of cherries, cola and anise. Drink now.

column2: Pali 2007 Thorn Ridge Ranch Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: Ripe and crisp and rich, in the manner of this fine vintage, offering an explosion of cherries, currants, anise and vanilla-scented cedar. With its silky texture, it's a beauty, but needs time. Give it 3–4 years in the cellar.

column2: Domaine Degher 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
column3: Lusty and fleshy, a fat, opulently flavored young Cab offering huge amounts of ripe Paso fruit. Floods the mouth with soft, somewhat one-dimensional flavors of blackberries, cherries, currants and sandalwood.

column2: Margerum 2011 Colson Canyon Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)
column3: A big wine, tannic and extracted in blackberry, blueberry and red currant flavors, with notes of bacon, mocha, black pepper and sandalwood. It shows plenty of class, but is still too young. Give until 2017 in the cellar.

column2: Lone Madrone 2006 Syrah (Paso Robles)
column3: Soft and gentle and very rich, with waves of red cherry, currant, chocolate, licorice and sweet spice flavors that go on and on. Really nice to drink with a grilled steak.

column2: Stephen & Walker 2006 Zinfandel (Sonoma County)
column3: A bit too soft for complete balance, but there's no denying the delicious Zinny flavors. Floods the mouth with peppery, spicy wild blackberries, red currants, licorice and beef jerky, all wrapped into firm, dry tannins. Drink now.

column2: Envy 2010 Calistoga Estate Petite Sirah (Napa Valley)
column3: This bottling has a solid track record from Envy, but the 2010 vintage, good as it is, is their least successful in years. While it's luscious with blackberry and blueberry jam, mocha and oak sweetness, it's one-dimensional, and lacking ageworthiness. Drink now, with sweet, smoky barbecued meats.

column2: Frei Brothers 2008 Merlot (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: An easy wine whose ripe fruit and oak flavors are immediately likeable. The cherries, raspberries and plums have a jammy sweetness, yet the tannins are firm. Easy to find, with 27,300 cases produced.

column2: Reynoso 2009 Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
column3: This polished young wine shows the softness and slight herbaceousness that mark many Alexander Valley Cabernets. With ripe blackberry, cherry pie, red currant and mocha flavors, it's a fine wine to drink now and over the next 4–5 years.

column2: Rochioli 2010 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: This is Rochioli's estate Pinot—without a vineyard designation. It's a fabulous wine, showing the winery's signature power, complexity and balance. The flavors are rich, with notes of red berries, persimmons, red currants, bacon and cola. Absolutely delicious now, and it should gain traction and change interestingly over 6–8 years.

column2: Christine Andrew 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Lodi)
column3: Good price for a sophisticated Cab you can substitute for more expensive bottlings without apologizing. The wine is rich in black currants, blackberry jam and spicy oak, accented by savory herbs and spices.

column2: Bennett Family 2005 The Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: From a label owned by William Grant & Sons, this rich Napa Cab meets expectations with its fine tannic structure and ripe, oak-influenced flavors of blackberries, currants, chocolate and spice. As sweet as the wine is in the mouth, it actually finishes thoroughly dry.

column2: Acacia 2010 Roberts Road Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: As delicious as Pinot Noir gets, this has fireworks of raspberries, cherries and cola, and a sweet, mushroom-like essence of earth. Then the depth kicks in. It's not a big, tannic wine, but rather soft, with enormous charm and immediate appeal. Drink now–2016.

column2: Marimar Estate 2008 Don Miguel Vineyard Syrah-Tempranillo (Russian River Valley)
column3: An ambitious wine that explores new blending territory. Shows fine structure, with brisk acidity and smooth tannins framing ripe cherry fruit, bacon and sandalwood flavors. Lacks a certain finesse, but definitely a worthwhile venture by the winery, and a wine to watch.

column2: Manzoni 2011 Home Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
column3: Strong, candied flavors of cola, cherries, rhubarb pie and persimmons mark this Pinot Noir. While it has a good structure of acids and tannins, and the alcohol isn't too high, it would benefit from greater subtlety and restraint.

column2: Manzoni 2011 Home Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
column3: Strong, candied flavors of cola, cherries, rhubarb pie and persimmons mark this Pinot Noir. While it has a good structure of acids and tannins, and the alcohol isn't too high, it would benefit from greater subtlety and restraint.

column2: Patz & Hall 2008 Pisoni Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
column3: Showing an enormous blast of cherries and raspberries, this Pinot is saved from being a fruit bomb by earthy, mushroomy complexities and a hit of acidity that makes the mouth water. It's way too young now, and should easily take 5–7 years in the cellar to come around.

column2: J. Lohr 2010 Gesture Zinfandel (Paso Robles)
column3: This wine gives plenty of sheer Zinny delight. The ripe, lush raspberry and blackberry flavors have a briary edge, with notes of wild nettles that give it a wildland personality. While the alcohol is high, it's in keeping with the wine's overall structure. Drink now with a great barbecued steak.

column2: Gary Farrell 2009 Stiling Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Dry and silky, this shows classic Russian River flavors of red cherries, red currants, cranberries, cola and pomegranates, with plenty of savory spices. The tannins are currently very strong; there will certainly be development over the next 5–6 years.

column2: Testarossa 2009 Graham Family Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: A little gritty in texture, and the rawness is compounded by black pepper tartness. Yet there's a huge, succulent core of black cherry fruit, and the wine is perfectly dry and acidic. An interesting Pinot, one to stash in the cellar and see what happens.

column2: Bianchi 2006 Zen Ranch Zinfandel (Paso Robles)
column3: So ripe and fruity, it's almost too much of a good thing. Detonates on the palate with blasts of blackberries, cherries, raspberries, cola and cinnamon spice. Feels too soft, and could use greater dryness and structure, but it's a good BBQ sipper.

column2: Krutz 2005 Stagecoach Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Very ripe, with powerful grilled blackberry, cassis and smoky oak flavors that are wrapped into strong tannins. The large vineyard is up on Atlas Peak, and the wine shows the slightly rustic, pugnacious quality that can mark Cabs of the appellation. Give it a few years to mellow.

column2: Valley Legend 2010 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: This Cabernet starts out tight and resistant. Although it has plenty of ripe cherry and blackberry fruit, there's something pinched about the mouthfeel. It's a good wine that will benefit from airing, but doesn't seem likely to improve in the cellar.

column2: Laetitia 2006 La Coupelle Pinot Noir (Arroyo Grande Valley)
column3: This is a first bottling of a new block in Laetitia's fine, large estate vineyard. It's a good wine, but not necessarily deserving of its own designation. Marked by crunchy acidity and tannins, it shows underlying flavors of cherries, cola and oak. Might age well, might not.

column2: Lost Canyon 2009 Goff-Whitton Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Exceptionally ripe fruit flavors of blackberry and cherry jam are brightened with crisp acidity in this dry, exotically spicy Pinot Noir. It's fine and silky in the mouth, with a brace of tannins. Drink over the next few years.

column2: Cupcake 2008 Pinot Noir (Central Coast)
column3: A delicious Pinot Noir. Set it beside more expensive bottlings and it stands up well. Silky and rich, with raspberry and cherry purée, cola, sweet vanilla and sandalwood flavors, and a long, spicy finish. Production was 26,000 cases.

column2: Cupcake 2008 Pinot Noir (Central Coast)
column3: A delicious Pinot Noir. Set it beside more expensive bottlings and it stands up well. Silky and rich, with raspberry and cherry purée, cola, sweet vanilla and sandalwood flavors, and a long, spicy finish. Production was 26,000 cases.

column2: Talley 2006 Estate Pinot Noir (Arroyo Grande Valley)
column3: Talley's basic estate Pinot can be good, and it can be ordinary. The '06 is pretty tannic and direct. It's a hard, tough wine that's not particularly lush, although it's clean and properly varietal. You'll find cherry and currant flavors that veer into raisins.

column2: Opus One 2006 Red (Napa Valley)
column3: A very good Opus with plenty of forward cherries and black raspberries as well as rich notes of spiced oak that give a nougat or crunchy vanilla granola sweetness to the finish. The vintage was not Opus One's best, but the wine is impeccably crafted, and shows its usual fine tannic structure.

column2: Milton Park 2009 Shiraz (South Australia)
column3: This wine may lack the dramatic power of its top-flight brethren, but it still satisfies, delivering reasonably complex notes of cherries, rhubarb and olive carried by silky tannins and moderate alcohol. Drink this terrific value over the next year or two.

column2: Billhook 2009 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: What a nice wine for drinking now and over the next few years. At the age of nearly four, it's mellow and rich, with the blackberry fruit and oak flavors achieving a savory marriage. Finishes dry, spicy and tart.

column2: Swanson 2009 Merlot (Oakville)
column3: Rich black-cherry, currant, licorice, spice and sandalwood flavors abound in this dry Merlot. It's pretty tannic, with a gum-sticking astringency. It's unlikely that this will age well, so drink it now, after decanting, and pair it with rich meats.

column2: Wellington 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
column3: A good buy in a Cabernet that's dry and elegant enough to pair with a great steak, chop or roast. It has classic blackberry, black currant, herb and cedar flavors, and is soft enough to drink now.

column2: Wellington 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
column3: A good buy in a Cabernet that's dry and elegant enough to pair with a great steak, chop or roast. It has classic blackberry, black currant, herb and cedar flavors, and is soft enough to drink now.

column2: Notre Vin 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)
column3: A huge wine, almost old-fashioned in its tannins. They're so strong, they freeze the palate with astringency, like a shot of Novacaine. It's also very dry, despite sweetly ripe blackberry essence, licorice and dark chocolate. All indications are that this is an ageworthy wine. Should begin to throw sediment and mellow in seven or eight years, and could go the distance to 2020 and beyond.

column2: Guarachi Family 2009 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: Dark and heavy for a Pinot Noir, although it's certainly well made and delicious. Floods the mouth with cherry and raspberry pie-filling fruit, and the smoky, caramelized oak has a granola sweetness. Drink now.

column2: Parcel 41 2011 Merlot (Napa Valley)
column3: This is a good value for a sophisticated Merlot from Napa Valley. It's not an ager, but it's delightful now for its dryness, smooth tannins and complex cherry and red currant flavors with hints of herbs and sweet peas.

column2: Bailiwick 2010 Foray Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: This feels lush and important right out of the bottle, tantalizing with tart cherry, cola and persimmon flavors that are wrapped in acids and tannins. Give it up to six years, and enjoy. All of the fruit comes from the Foray Vineyard in the Green Valley.

column2: The Magpie 2010 Lot Four Cabernet Sauvignon (St. Helena)
column3: Shows the sweet richness of Napa Valley. It has candied flavors of blackberries and cherries, wrapped into firm, polished tannins. A pretty wine, it should show its best over the next four years.

column2: Liberty School 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
column3: Great price for a Cabernet this nice. It's dry, smooth and classic in blackberry and currant flavors, with a deft touch of smoky oak. Just a bit too acidic; a rich steak will help.

column2: Wild Oak by St. Francis 2005 Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
column3: A good Cab, dry and balanced, whose tannins are richly impressive and sweet. Shows a good tension between the oak and the ripe black currants. Easy to like, and should develop for a few years.

column2: Keller 2009 La Cruz Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: Very rich and elegantly structured, this shows the talented viticulture and superior winemaking. Bone dry, it has powerful flavors of cherry pie filling, cola and pomegranate, with a mouthwatering spiciness. The acidity is notable. Try pairing this with a salted and peppered steak.

column2: Frick 2007 Owl Hill Vineyard Estate Bottled Counoise (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: A bit sharp and weedy, and very dry, but it's a good, clean wine that trades structure for richness. Strong acids and tannins frame herb-infused flavors of cherries and red currants, with a veneer of sweet oak. Drink now.

column2: Tower 15 2011 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
column3: You can taste the warm Paso Robles sunshine in every sip of this exuberant Cabernet. It brims with jammy blackberries, black cherries and chocolate, yet the finish is dry. Be aware of quite high alcohol, though, that gives it prickly heat.

column2: V. Sattui 2005 Preston Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Robust in tannins, with crisp, fruity acidity, this Cab has very ripe, jammy blackberry and cherry flavors that have seen their share of smoky oak. It's a good wine but an edgy one. Could develop in the bottle after a couple years.

column2: Perbacco Cellars 2005 Dionysus Pinot Noir (Arroyo Grande Valley)
column3: Far richer and more concentrated than the winery's regular '05 Pinot, this is a true reserve. It shows the same dryness and silky texture, but the spicy fruit is more intense in cherries and black raspberries, veering into cassis and anisette. Drink now for its extravagent flavors.

column2: Mounts 2007 Estate Grown Cabernet Franc (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: A little too hot and brawny in tannins, which provides a cut across the palate that interferes with pleasure. If you can get past that, the wine is nicely dry and rich in fruit, with cherry, tobacco, spice and oak flavors.

column2: Francis Ford Coppola 2009 Director's Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
column3: Made from 100% Cabernet, this is a fine everyday wine. It's dry, full-bodied and satisfying in blackberry, cola and currant flavors, with a nice kiss of oak. The alcohol level is nice and low. Ready to drink now.

column2: Jack Nicklaus Wines 2009 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Rich and opulent, in the popular style, this Cabernet offers soft, oak-driven flavors of blackberries, black cherries and cherry liqueur. It's a gentle, delicious and fancy wine, if a little one-dimensional. Drink now.

column2: Jaffurs 2008 Syrah (Santa Barbara County)
column3: A lusty, soft Syrah, packed with flavor, for drinking now with rich meats and stews. Dry and tannic, it bursts with blackberries, black currants, cocoa and pepper, with an edge of green mint.

column2: Riboli 2009 Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)
column3: This is sharper and more rustic than most other expensive Rutherford Cabernets, with a cut of citrusy acidity that dominates the cherry and herb flavors. While it's tough and hard to appreciate now, you never know if these aggressive young wines will develop with time. This one doesn't seem like it will benefit, so drink up.

column2: Alysian 2008 Rochioli Vineyard River Block Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Green tannins mark this dry Pinot Noir, and the astringency accentuates the acidity, giving the wine a harsh mouthfeel. Although it has expressive cherry, pomegranate and cola flavors, it's a big disappointment, coming from this famous vineyard and block.

column2: Hunter Ashby 2005 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Black currant and cherry flavors, accented with a touch of smoky oak, mark this dry, smooth wine. It has the textural hallmarks of the best of Napa Valley Cabernet, but lacks the richness. Drink now.

column2: August West 2011 Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
column3: There's an unripe, vegetal note that interferes with the enjoyment of this Pinot Noir. Although the wine is nicely dry, crisp and elegantly structured, with some good raspberry and cherry fruit, that taste of asparagus is hard to get over.

column2: Longboard 2010 Ledbetter Family Vineyard Syrah (Russian River Valley)
column3: A faint but persistent vegetal note immediately leaps out beyond the sweet black raspberries, plums and oak, showing the difficulties of the cool vintage. It's softly tannic in the mouth and dry, but not going anywhere, so drink up.

column2: Ridge 2007 Three Valleys Zinfandel (Sonoma County)
column3: An absolutely beautiful Zin, and a must-have for restaurant wine lists. It's pure and complex in blackberries, cherries, cola and mocha, with wonderful spices erupting all the way though, and the most elegant silky texture. What a great job.

column2: Robert John 2010 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Rich flavors of blackberry jam, cassis and toasty oak mark this dry, tannic young Cab. It's not showing much subtlety or grace, but that may be a function of youth. Give it six years and see what it does.

column2: Roadhouse Winery 2010 Orange Label Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Dry and silky, this is a good Pinot Noir, though it's a little too ripe, which gives the blackberry and cherry notes a pruny, hot taste. Try it with beef stew and prunes to echo the flavors.

column2: Castello di Amorosa 2009 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: They held this Cab back for nearly four years, but it's still pretty closed and tannic. Give it another six in the cellar, to let it begin to throw some sediment, which will let the blackberries and cherries drink sweet and pure.

column2: Lamborn Family Vineyards 2006 Serendipity Zinfandel (Howell Mountain)
column3: This high-octane wine will please lovers of big, powerful Zinfandel. It's a little hot from high alcohol, but so lush, you hardly notice. Offers waves of currants, anise and pepper that go on and on, and the finish is dry.

column2: Rued 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: Shows the briary, scoury mouthfeel that so often characterizes Dry Creek Valley red wines, as opposed to the smooth lushness of neighboring Napa Valley. The flavors are just fine, of wild blackberries, cherries and cola. Drink over the next six years.

column2: Twomey 2009 Bien Nacido Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)
column3: Lots of ripe strawberries, raspberries and sweet smoky oak in this silky young Pinot Noir. It tastes a bit too extracted and jammy for subtlety, but sure does offer a mouthful of flavor.

column2: Eric Kent 2006 Dry Stack Vineyard Syrah (Bennett Valley)
column3: Kind of tough in texture, with hard tannins that make for an astringent mouthfeel. The question is, will it age? Maybe for a little while, but it's always going to have that rough edge to the blackberries, currants, pepper and cedar.

column2: Hobo 2008 Branham Rockpile Vineyard Zinfandel (Rockpile)
column3: A beautiful Zin, dry and spicy. Shows lush, intricate flavors of blackberries, black raspberries, anise, pepper, cola and cedar. A very fine interpretation of a dusty Sonoma Zinfandel.

column2: Hobo 2008 Branham Rockpile Vineyard Zinfandel (Rockpile)
column3: A beautiful Zin, dry and spicy. Shows lush, intricate flavors of blackberries, black raspberries, anise, pepper, cola and cedar. A very fine interpretation of a dusty Sonoma Zinfandel.

column2: Muirwood 2007 Suter Vineyard Pinot Noir (Arroyo Seco)
column3: A lighter, elegant style of Pinot Noir, dry and silky, with cherryskin, tobacco, cola and sweet oak flavors, wrapped into furry tannins. This is a good price. Drink now.

column2: Liberty School 2010 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
column3: This is a fine Cabernet to drink with burgers, Mexican food, beef stew or skirt steak. Soft and sweet, it has flavors of blackberries and cherries, plus a just-right jacket of smoky oak and a smooth, spicy finish.

column2: Cuvaison 2007 Syrah (Carneros)
column3: Rather heavy and super-fruity now, with fruitstand flavors of blackberries, cherries and plums. It's a ripely delicious wine, but a bit one-dimensional, not showing much elegance or subtlety. Could develop bottle nuance over the next 4–6 years.

column2: Renteria 2009 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Smooth, dry and tannic, but a little thin, this is not one for the cellar. Shows some nice blackberry, black currant and oak flavors, with marked Napa elegance and balance. Drink up.

column2: Keenan 2007 Merlot (Napa Valley)
column3: A delicious Merlot, drily tannic and rich in blackberries, cherries and chocolate. Nearly as good as the winery's much more expensive Reserve. Great with grilled steak with sautéed mushrooms.

column2: Keenan 2007 Merlot (Napa Valley)
column3: A delicious Merlot, drily tannic and rich in blackberries, cherries and chocolate. Nearly as good as the winery's much more expensive Reserve. Great with grilled steak with sautéed mushrooms.

column2: Dutton Estate 2007 Dutton Ranch Karmen Isabella Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Easy to like a lot now for its terrifically rich flavors of cherries, raspberries, pomegranates, mocha and smoky sandalwood flavors that take over and dazzle the palate. Also shows a silky, airy mouthfeel. But it's way too young now, an obvious ager, and in fact demands time in the bottle. Stash this beauty. Best 2011–2013, possibly longer.

column2: Bella 2010 Barrel 32 Zinfandel (Sonoma County)
column3: Nothing subtle about this Zin, which offers a heady blast of grilled raspberries and cherries. It's a robust wine, with lots of alcohol and spices and a rich finish. This is your go-to summer barbecue wine.

column2: Bennett Lane 2009 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Softly tannic and sinfully rich, a drink-me-now Cabernet that offers plenty of upscale Napa pleasure. The flavors are intricate, offering tiers of blackberry and cherry jam, currant, mocha and toasty oak.

column2: Crossbarn by Paul Hobbs 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Quite a distinguished Cabernet. Shows its pedigree in ultra-refined tannins and an overall mouthfeel of lushness and finesse. Flavor-wise, it's all black currants, blueberries and sweet, smoky oak. Thirty-five dollars isn't cheap, but this is as good as it gets in this price bracket.

column2: Cable Car 2009 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)
column3: Acidic and rustic, but rich in fruit, this Cab shows lots of cherries, blackberries and briary wild berries. It's an easy wine to drink, and the price is pretty good.

column2: Baileyana 2007 La Entrada Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)
column3: Considerably riper than Baileyana's other Pinots. It shows in the richer, softer mouthfeel and deeper flavors. The red cherries veer toward blackberries, yet the texture remains silky and dry. New oak, as always, is judiciously applied. Delicious now, and should develop over the next 3–4 years.

column2: Hunnicutt 2006 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Rich and ripe, with enormous blackberry, currant, chocolate and cedar flavors, wrapped into firm but smoothly complex tannins. A very good Cab that will develop nuances over the next 4–6 years.

column2: Carr 2007 Cabernet Franc (Santa Ynez Valley)
column3: A hot, rather brutal wine. High alcohol combines with high, hard tannins to make for a real textural challenge, despite interesting cherry, licorice and Canadian bacon flavors. Drink now.

column2: Valley of the Moon 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
column3: A good, dry Cabernet whose fruit flavors are balanced with rich tannins. Offers upfront flavors of blackberries, cherries, raspberries and cocoa. Good price, considering the elegance

column2: Sojourn 2008 Rodgers Creek Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: High in acidity, with a nice silky texture and bone dry. It's a very good wine, but despite some modest cherry, raspberry and licorice flavors, it lacks richness, particularly at this price.

column2: San Simeon 2009 Pinot Noir (Monterey)
column3: A good everyday Pinot Noir, tart in acids and with some edgy tannins. But it has the variety's nice, silky texture, with rich cherry, rosehip tea and sandalwood flavors.

column2: Blackstone 2007 Sonoma Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
column3: A good everyday Cabernet with some aspirations to quality. Even though it's a little rugged and harsh in tannins, it's dry, with oak-inspired flavors of blackberries, black currants, cola and herbs. Drink now.

column2: Turnbull 2009 Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Softly delicious, this Cabernet is perfect for drinking now. Its blackberry, currant and cocoa flavors are housed in wonderfully ripe, accessible tannins. Shows the elegance of a superior Napa Cab.

column2: Rendition 2007 Petite Sirah (Alexander Valley)
column3: Great price for a big, powerful red like this. Tough in tannins now, it shows classic flavors of currants, mocha, anise and pepper, and will develop over time. Classy and impressive.

column2: Cameron Hughes 2011 Lot 385 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Here's a nice Cabernet with some extra features of elegance. It's not for the cellar, but shows polished blackberry, currant and mocha flavors, wrapped into pretty strong, dry tannins. Give it an hour in the decanter and drink now.

column2: August Ridge 2007 Estate Grown Sangiovese (Paso Robles)
column3: High alcohol marks this wine, giving it a burn, especially after you swallow. Other than that, it's soft in acids and tannins, with cherry and currant flavors. At nearly six years old, it's giving its best now.

column2: Starmont 2009 Merlot (Napa Valley)
column3: Good, deep flavors of blackberries, currants and spices mark this dry wine. It has a coating of smoky new oak. The texture is a bit harsh, which is really its only minus. Otherwise, it's a nice Merlot to drink now.

column2: Huntington 2005 Hidden Hill Vineyard Syrah (Alexander Valley)
column3: Deliciously gentle. Makes you wonder why more people don't drink Syrah. With a soft complexity, the wine houses lush flavors of cherries, plums, mocha and violets, accented with sweet, smoky oak.

column2: Williams Selyem 2006 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Very dry, tart and silky, this is a great Williams Selyem Pinot to drink now. It shows the classic elegance of the appellation, with nuanced flavors of raspberries, cherries, red currants, cloves, anise and pepper.

column2: Bonaccorsi 2010 Bien Nacido Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)
column3: A terrific Pinot, wonderful for drinking now, and should develop some bottle complexity over the next 5–6 years. Really shows off that flashy Bien Nacido character, offering wildly rich cherry and persimmon flavors, balanced with brisk acidity and a dusting of fuzzy tannins.

column2: Silverado 2010 Mt. George Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: This Cabernet is a guaranteed cellar candidate. It's enormously rich and extracted, with flavors of blackberries, currants, plums and mocha, but finishes firm, dry and tannic. Give it at least four more years in a cellar.

column2: Stuhlmuller Vineyards 2008 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
column3: For those looking for a leaner, earthier but still-stylish Cabernet, this is the ticket. It's very dry, with soft Alexander Valley tannins and flavors of blackberries, cherries and herbs. This elegant young wine could easily develop fascinating bottle complexities over the next 8–10 years.

column2: Collier Falls 2010 Hillside Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: Lots of rich, extracted cherry pie, chocolate and cassis flavors in this soft, oaky Cabernet. It's a little sweet and hot, but will drink well now with grilled steak.

column2: Sterling 2009 Platinum Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: This is soft, ripe and delicious, in the cult style, with heady blackberry jam, chocolate and sweet, caramelized oak flavors. It's thoroughly dry and really easy to like, with a certain dramatic impact. Drink soon.

column2: Midnight 2010 Nebula Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
column3: This is the winery's best Nebula in years. While it's still a little on the soft, sweet side, the cool vintage has resonated in the wine's flavor, giving it a good structure housing cherry, currant and sandalwood flavors. Drink now.

column2: Midnight 2010 Nebula Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
column3: This is the winery's best Nebula in years. While it's still a little on the soft, sweet side, the cool vintage has resonated in the wine's flavor, giving it a good structure housing cherry, currant and sandalwood flavors. Drink now.

column2: Patton Valley 2011 Lorna Marie Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: The Lorna Marie is the winery's reserve-level bottling, and gets the most new oak, about 60%. In this vintage, the fruit seems a bit thin, almost watery, although with some hours of breathing it gains some palate traction. It's well made, but don't look for reserve-level heft.

column2: Blackbird Vineyards 2007 Paramour Red (Napa Valley)
column3: Some wines are meant for immediate consumption. Others require age. This wonderful wine satisfies on both sides. It's softly rich and polished in tannins, with accessible blackberry, cassis and oak flavors. Yet it has the structure and depth to go for years. Now–2016, at least.

column2: Rodney Strong 1998 Alexander's Crown Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
column3: Of this winery's two new releases, the less expensive is better, because this usually fine release is from the infamous ‘98 vintage. It just can't overcome a basic thinness and wateriness, despite an obvious pedigree and plush oak. That said, it's a good wine. The ‘99 will undoubtedly be much better.

column2: Courtney Benham 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
column3: A lovely Cabernet. Shows the softness and herbaceousness that mark Alexander Valley Cabs, but in a good way, with a streak of red cherries, tobacco and sandalwood. Fine now with a good steak.

column2: Kynsi 2009 Precious Stone Stone Corral Vineyard Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)
column3: There's a mushroom note to this Pinot that gives it an earthy richness, helping to ground the ripe, jammy raspberry and cherry flavors. This is Kynsi's best '09 Pinot Noir, but you should give it 1–3 years in the bottle to let everything integrate.

column2: Frog's Leap 2006 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Although it's not on a par with Frog's Leap recent Cabernets, this '06 still is a nice glass of wine. It's dry and pretty tannic, with easy flavors of black currants and cedar. Might develop some bottle complexities over the next few years.

column2: Paraiso Vineyards 2006 West Terrace Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
column3: Best to give this young Pinot a year or two in the cellar, because it's a little too closed to completely enjoy now. It doesn't show the generosity of the '01 or '05, but is more tannic and a little earthier. Should mellow through 2009 and let the cherry flavors emerge.

column2: Bell 2004 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: There's a lot to praise and also lots to criticize in this Cab. It's richly tannic and nicely oaked, with lush black currant and smoky oak flavors. But it also has a harshness that interferes with enjoyment. Doesn't seem likely to age out.

column2: Roberts & Rogers 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)
column3: Big, powerful and flashy, this is made in the modern cult style, showing ripeness, high alcohol and oakiness. The blackberry and cassis flavors are classic Napa, while the texture is smooth and mellow, but as heady as cognac.

column2: Collier Falls 2004 Hillside Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: Tastes soft and a little tired at the age of six-plus years, with pie-filling raspberry, cherry and spice flavors. A certain dry complexity makes it interesting, but its lifespan is largely exhausted.

column2: Loring Wine Company 2007 Rosella's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
column3: Enormously rich, this Pinot Noir has gigantic fruit flavors of blackberries, cherries, raspberries, cola, mocha, anise and pepper. Some will call it a fruit bomb because it doesn't have much structure to balance all that extravagance.

column2: Flora Springs 2008 Wild Boar Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Dry, hard tannins mark this wine. Made from Pope Valley fruit, it's rich in blackberries, currants, herbs and chocolate. Feels somewhat coarse at this point, but could age well. It's a gamble.

column2: Williams Selyem 2009 Eastside Road Neighbors Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Marked by immediately likeable fruit in the form of raspberries and cherries, this pleasant Pinot has a rich coating of sweet, smoky oak. It's the most accessible of Williams Selyem's new releases.

column2: Pine Ridge 2010 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Lots of tough, old-fashioned tannins on this pugnacious young Cabernet. While it has a good core of blackberries and currants, it's pretty brutal on the palate. Hard to tell if the fruit will outlast the astringency. Try after 2018.

column2: Michael James Wines 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Lots of forward fruit flavor in this ripe Cabernet. It floods the mouth with blackberries, cherries and currants, with a smoky overlay of oak. Not particularly subtle, but it defines the modern style of Cabernet, and lots of people will love it.

column2: Mettler Family Vineyards 2007 Epicenter Old Vine Zinfandel (Lodi)
column3: Some Zins handle high alcohol well, and so it is with this lusty, delicious example from Lodi. It's soft and easy to drink, with rich flavors of berries, cherries, currants, smoky oak and spices that turn chocolaty on the finish.

column2: Oak Grove 2010 Reserve Zinfandel (California)
column3: What Americans need is a good $8 Zinfandel, and what do you know? That's just what this is. Dry as dust but sweet in fruit, with all kinds of savory spices, this is the perfect everyday wine for barbecue. Production was 8,000 cases, so it shouldn't be too hard to find.

column2: Cumbre of Vine Hill 2006 Hicks Family Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)
column3: Shows the dramatic way that this mountainous region south of San Francisco can ripen Pinot Noir to such perfection. Brilliant in raspberry, cherry, sassafras, mocha, anise and cinnamon flavors, with rich notes of smoky cedar, it shows enough tannins to age it for a few years.

column2: Reaper 2012 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Rich blackberry and currant flavors mark this Cabernet. It's bone dry, very tannic and acidic, giving it a severe mouthfeel that's not likely to age out. But it's elegant and food-friendly. Decant it for a few hours.

column2: Ricardus Corculum 2007 ClandestZin Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: Super-fruity and ultra-soft, with flavors of raspberries, cherries, red currants, bacon, cocoa, cola and lots of peppery spices. It's a nice Zin to drink with BBQ.

column2: Sbragia 2006 Rancho Del Oso Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)
column3: This is the most accessible, most interesting and most compelling of Sbragia's new Cabernets. It's extraordinarily powerful in the potent, sweetly refined tannins and ripe flavors of blackberries and cassis, leading to a long, rich finish. You can drink it now, but it will age effortlessly for a good 8–10 years.

column2: Lawer 2009 Three Coins Betsy's Vineyard Syrah (Knights Valley)
column3: This is rich and dry in blackberries, licorice, bacon, sweet oak and peppery spices. It shows lots of acidity and tannins, giving it a firm structure. Give it a brief decant and drink now.

column2: Stepping Stone by Cornerstone 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Somewhat soft and jammy. While it's certainly delicious, this 100% Cabernet needs greater structure and complexity to add value to the sweet blackberries, cherries and chocolate.

column2: Clos La Chance 2008 Erwin Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)
column3: You'll find a nice, silky texture on this Pinot Noir, as well as lush flavors of cherries, raspberries, cola, sweet tobacco and dusty baking spices. There's some sharpness all the way through that detracts.

column2: Kenefick Ranch 2007 Caitlin's Select Cabernet Franc (Calistoga)
column3: Almost too ripe and fruity, with jammy, pie-filling blackberry and cherry flavors. Lots of oak, too, giving the wine a caramelized sweetness. A bit heavy-handed, but tasty. Drink now.

column2: Tin Roof 2005 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)
column3: A nice glass of Cab for $13. It's bone dry, with a scour of sandpapery tannins, and hints of cherries, blackberries, plums, cola and cedar. Shows real class for a statewide-appellated Cab at this price.

column2: Pedroncelli 2008 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: This is a very dry, silky Pinot Noir made in a more restrained manner than some of the big, huge ones out there. It doesn't whack your head, but appeals for its elegance. Shows sophisticated cherry, sassafras and sandalwood flavors, and the price is extremely good for the quality.

column2: Fritz 2009 Reserve Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: A flamboyantly rich wine, elaborate in cherry, pomegranate, persimmon and cola flavors that are deep and impressive. Yet there's good structure, with soft acidity and a gentle coating of tannins. Drink over the next four years.

column2: Bridgeview 1998 Reserve Pinot Noir (Rogue Valley)
column3: Beets, mint and cola mark the aromas of this robust offering from the southern part of the state. It’s rich and corpulent—almost Port-like in its dimensions—and although it lacks a bit of elegance, it certainly possesses plenty of mouth-filling flavor.

column2: Geyser Peak 2005 Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
column3: This is a beautiful Cabernet for drinking now. It's soft and lush and dry, with complex flavors of red and black currants, sweet herbs and cedar. Shows real class and elegance.

column2: Stone Edge Farm 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma Valley)
column3: Not showing much pleasure right out of the bottle, with a sharp, tannic mouthfeel. There's a deep core of black currant fruit that veers into overripe raisins. Might age, but it's risky.

column2: La Sirena 2004 Syrah (Napa Valley)
column3: No questioning the ripeness of this Syrah. It floods the mouth with jammy cherries, blueberries, currants and chocolate, with a peppery edge accented by smoky new oak. A bit soft and obvious in its palate appeal, it's at its best now and for a couple years.

column2: Lyeth 2010 Meritage (Sonoma County)
column3: An easy, gentle wine, soft and velvety in texture, offering jammy flavors of blackberries, cherries, raspberries and oak. Earns extra points for dryness and a richly tannic structure.

column2: Lyeth 2010 Meritage (Sonoma County)
column3: An easy, gentle wine, soft and velvety in texture, offering jammy flavors of blackberries, cherries, raspberries and oak. Earns extra points for dryness and a richly tannic structure.

column2: Emblem 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)
column3: This is a very good Cab to drink now for its firm, dry mouthfeel and ripe flavors of cherries, currants and cedar. It feels elegant and distinguished. But it's also thick in dusty tannins, and should slowly evolve in the bottle for 6–7 years.

column2: Lafond 2009 Lafond Vineyard Martin Ray Clone Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
column3: Made in the earthy style this pioneering winery is known for, showing mushroom-inflected wild strawberries, spices and sandalwood. The acid-tannin balance is such that this Pinot could age up to 6–8 years.

column2: Sawyer 2005 Estate Merlot (Rutherford)
column3: Nice and dry, with good currant, cherry, olive and oak flavors, but the tannins are quite tough, giving the wine great astringency. Doesn't seem to have the stuffing for the cellar, so drink up.

column2: Unti 2006 Syrah (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: With ripe blackberry and cherry flavors, the fruit of this dry wine stands out, making it enjoyable despite very tough tannins that currently make it astringently sandpapery. A good effort, although the challenge for Unti is to tame those fierce tannins.

column2: Renteria 2010 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: A wonderfully drinkable Pinot Noir, this wine shows the brisk acidity and long hangtime flavors of the Sonoma Coast. The fruit got exceptionally ripe, so the raspberries, cherries and persimmons are as sweet as jam. Yet the finish is dry and firm.

column2: Pomar Junction 2007 Syrah (Monterey County)
column3: This wine comes from the San Lucas area of the southern Salinas Valley, on the way toward Paso Robles. It's a peppery wine, rustic, hot and dry, with strong jammy flavors of cherries and blackberries, and a long, spicy finish. Drink now.

column2: Pomar Junction 2007 Syrah (Monterey County)
column3: This wine comes from the San Lucas area of the southern Salinas Valley, on the way toward Paso Robles. It's a peppery wine, rustic, hot and dry, with strong jammy flavors of cherries and blackberries, and a long, spicy finish. Drink now.

column2: Freeman 2007 Keefer Ranch Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Shows the grace and beauty that characterize this fine vineyard, and also the integrity of the vintage. Firm tannins and tart acidity frame ripe flavors of cherries, pomegranates, cola and sandalwood. Excellent, but needs time. Best mid-2010 through 2013.

column2: Kirkland Signature 2011 Series Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)
column3: This is a good price for a Cabernet this rich and satisfying. It's dry, tannic and opulent in blackberries, black currants and mocha, with a complex note of green olives. It's fully ready to drink now.

column2: Kirkland Signature 2011 Series Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)
column3: This is a good price for a Cabernet this rich and satisfying. It's dry, tannic and opulent in blackberries, black currants and mocha, with a complex note of green olives. It's fully ready to drink now.

column2: Vine Hill 2009 Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)
column3: Rich and satisfying, it has a ton of cherry and cola fruit that is wrapped into firm tannins and made brisk with acidity. The finish is dry and spicy. Not an ager, but it's a beautiful wine to drink now with a great steak.

column2: Nova Vita 2008 Petit Verdot (Paso Robles)
column3: Brims with briary blackberry fruit, spicy and ripe, enhanced with a layer of oak. It's a little jammy and hot, and also is quite tannic, but there's a firm nobility in there. Give it a good decant and enjoy.

column2: William Knuttel 2007 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: A nice Pinot Noir, dry and elegant, and if it's somewhat one-dimensional, it packs a lot of flavor. With rich raspberry, red licorice, bacon and spice flavors, it's a lovely wine to drink now.

column2: Sterling 2005 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: A sturdy Cab with some hard, edgy tannins that bite, but with enough black currant and spice flavors to satisfy. Might even soften and mellow with a year or so in the bottle.

column2: Tercero 2007 Thompson Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)
column3: Feels too soft and rather one-dimensional, although the flavors are very good. The best thing about the wine, aside from dryness, is the richness of tannins. The fruit veers toward blackberry marmalade and currants. Doesn't seem like an ager, so drink up.

column2: La Jota Vineyard 2009 Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)
column3: The tannins are so fierce on this baby Cabernet that they effectively lock it down and make it tough to drink now. Yet there's a fabulous core of blackberries that are rich, ripe and intense. Everything about it suggests ageability. Give it at least eight years in a proper cellar, and it could age even longer.

column2: La Jota Vineyard 2009 Merlot (Howell Mountain)
column3: The tannins are so fierce on this baby Cabernet that they effectively lock it down and make it tough to drink now. Yet there's a fabulous core of blackberries that are rich, ripe and intense. Everything about it suggests ageability. Give it at least eight years in a proper cellar, and it could age even longer.

column2: Fleming Jenkins 2007 Black Ridge Vineyard Syrah (Santa Cruz Mountains)
column3: Marked by an enormity of ripe, classic Syrah flavor, but also lots of intense mountain tannins that make this wine austere and hard in youth. Give it 2–4 years to begin to soften and allow the blackberries and cocoa to emerge.

column2: Summers 2009 Cabernet Sauvignon (Calistoga)
column3: Made in a dry, earthy style, this wine chooses elegance and structure over dazzling opulence. And that's just fine. It has a good core of blackberry and currant fruit, and the balance suggests some time in the cellar. Give it 3–4 years.

column2: Lamborn Family Vineyards 2011 The Pupil Zinfandel (Howell Mountain)
column3: Lamborn has a knack for Zinfandel grown on Howell Mountain. The 2011 is dry, tannic and high in alcohol, but also concentrated with flavors of currants, blackstrap molasses, licorice and cedar. It could benefit from some time in the bottle so hold until 2016.

column2: Judd's Hill 1999 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Good and rich and classy, with excellently ripe blackberry, currant and herb flavors and a nice overlay of toasty oak. Tannins are as fine as can be, smooth and complex, although they're young and tend to stun the palate.

column2: Kirkland Signature 2008 Mountain Cuvée Cabernet (Napa Valley)
column3: A very rich, ripe, opulent Cabernet, fulsome in blackberries, blueberries, currants and licorice, nicely framed in sweet, smoky oak. Easy to drink now for its soft tannins.

column2: Provenance Vineyards 2005 Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)
column3: Spicy, smoky new oak leaps out of the glass, like a blast of caramelized meringue, but the fruit is so rich that the oak is in balance. The underlying flavors of blackberries, licorice and chocolate are, in a word, delicious. Now through 2011.

column2: Mahoney 2004 Pinot Noir (Carneros)
column3: Francis Mahoney has crafted a young, expressive Pinot Noir, and while it's not particularly complex, it shows real Carneros terroir. Dry and balanced, the wine has cherry, mushroom and earthy flavors, balanced with rich acids and a dusting of tannins. Drink now.

column2: Furthermore 2010 Sierra Mar Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
column3: The fruit of this Pinot Noir is fantastically ripe, a testament to the California sun and the long growing season of the Santa Lucia Highlands. The wine is enormous in raspberries and cherries that are jammy, yet finish dry. The acidity also is notable, cutting the richness with citrusy tartness that may limit ageability. Drink now–2016.

column2: Arrowood 1999 Grand Archer Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
column3: From master winemaker Dick Arrowood, and pretty good for a regional-based wine. A politically correct Cabernet with cassis flavors, good oak, very dry, stylish tannins and low acidity. There's not a lot going on below the surface but it gets the job done.

column2: Joseph Phelps 2009 Larry Hyde & Sons Vineyard Syrah (Napa Valley)
column3: This wine, which is from the Napa side of the sprawling Carneros appellation, is superb. It's soft, rich and chocolaty, with a rich vein of ripe blackberries, but it also has a tannic structure and dry finish that make it balanced and complex. Drink now–2015.

column2: Domaine Chandon 2010 Pinot Noir (Carneros)
column3: A festive, elegant Pinot for drinking  now with fine fare, such as lamb, steak, salmon or tuna. It's crisp, silky and dry, yet there's a core of ripe raspberry and cherry essence enriched with toasty oak.

column2: Terlato 2008 Cardinal's Peak Red (Napa Valley)
column3: Fruit-forward, showing ripe, sweet blackberry, cherry, blueberry and cocoa flavors, elaborately uplifted by toasty oak. Made in the modern style, it's rich and delicious now.

column2: Calicaro 2010 Paris Mountain Lone Oak Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)
column3: Good structure in this Pinot, with firm tannins and fine coastal acidity. It shows jammy raspberry, cherry and cola flavors whose sweetness is echoed by the toasty oak. It's all a bit unresolved, but give it 5–6 years to knit together.

column2: Juliet 2005 Juliet Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Tastes direct and ripe, with pie-filling, almost sweet flavors of blackberries, black cherries and smoky oak. Could improve over the short term.

column2: Semper 2007 Gold Ridge Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: An extraordinary wine. It's the essence of Russian River Pinot, squared, a big, concentrated, dramatic wine that never loses sight of elegance. Offers a tapestry of cherry pie with the crust, red currant, cherry liqueur and smoky sandalwood flavors that finish with intricate Indian spices. Drink now–2013.

column2: St. Francis 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
column3: Good price for a nicely complex Cabernet for drinking now. Dry and smooth in tannins, it shows ripe blackberry, cherry, licorice and herb flavors, with a kiss of oak.

column2: Chime 2012 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)
column3: Pretty good Cabernet for the price. It's dry and zippy in acidity, with blackberry, red currant, licorice and toasty oak flavors that go down nice and easy.

column2: Stryker Sonoma 2010 Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
column3: Masses of sweet blackberry jam give this Cabernet an easy deliciousness. The fruit and oak are balanced with fine tannins and a gentle scour of acidity. Not one for the cellar, but it will benefit from an hour or two in the decanter.

column2: Truett Hurst 2009 Rattler Rock Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: Classic Dry Creek Zinfandel, dry and brawny and high in alcohol. Pair the wild blackberry, nettle, anise and pepper flavors with a spice-rubbed, smoky grilled steak.

column2: Big Ass 2005 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: The name is apropos, for this is a big, fleshy wine, almost like one of those Aussie Shirazes in jammy fruit, although it's Cabernet all the way with blackberries and currants. With fine tannins and a smooth finish, it shows quite a bit of sophistication.

column2: Round Hill 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)
column3: A pretty good Cabernet for this everyday price. It's very dry and rich in tannins, with sweet-and-sour flavors of cherries, herbs and mint. Fine for an inexpensive, by-the-glass program.

column2: Artesa 2011 Elements Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
column3: As the name suggests, this is an elemental Cabernet, offering pleasant blackberry, cherry and oak flavors. Rich and ripe in California sunshine fruit, it's smooth in tannins and easy to drink.

column2: Janzen 2010 Beckstoffer To Kalon Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)
column3: Enormously rich and complex, with blackberry and currant flavors accompanied by notes of green olives and new oak. The tannins are thick, but ripe. Way too young to drink now due to the closed-down astringency, the wine practically begs to be cellared. Give it 6–10 years.

column2: MacMurray Ranch 2006 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: If you had the resources to analyze what makes a picture postcard-perfect Russian River Pinot Noir, and then to actually produce it in case quantities, this is what you'd come up with. The wine is dry and silky and crisply acidic, with pleasant cherry, root beer and spice flavors. It's as friendly as can be and fully ready now.

column2: Kessler-Haak 2011 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
column3: Right now, the wine is tart in acidity and tannic, although the ripe cherry and red currant flavors are obvious and delicious. The oak influence is strong. The wine doesn't seem to be a longterm ager, but it should benefit from cellaring until 2017.

column2: Kenwood 2005 Zinfandel (Sonoma County)
column3: A fine Zin from some of Sonoma's best vineyards. Briary and rustic, it brims with dry, savory flavors of wild berries, cherries and spices, with a rich finish that goes on for a good 30 seconds.

column2: Madrigal 2008 Cabernet Franc (Calistoga)
column3: So sweet and rich in cherry, vanilla and cinnamon spice flavors, what's not to like? It's dry, gentle in tannins and complex. Seems designed for easy pairing with a great steak.

column2: Cuvaison 2010 Pinot Noir (Carneros)
column3: One of Cuvaison's best basic Pinots in years, this is charming with its dry, crisp structure, silky elegance and fine flavors of raspberries, cherries and toasty oak. While not an ager, it's a beautiful wine to pair with tuna, salmon, lamb or steak.

column2: Houdini 2008 Palisades Ranch Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Tough in the mouth, and chewy, like a gristly piece of steak you can't quite break down. It's certainly rich in blackberry, black currant and smoky oak flavors, and is properly dry and brisk in acidity. But you have to wonder if that toughness will ever age out.

column2: Perception 2007 Bacigalupi Vineyard Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)
column3: Starts with a funky smell that doesn't go away despite lots of airing. Underneath that is a very dry, very tannic and deeply flavored Zinfandel, rich in berries, cola and spices. That barnyardy smell is troubling.

column2: Peju 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: A lovely Cabernet for drinking now. It's soft and harmonious, with ripe, sweet flavors of blackberries, cherries and anise liqueur. An elaborate coating of oak brings a sweet, smoky deliciousness.

column2: Carol Shelton 2007 Rocky Reserve Florence Vineyard Zinfandel (Rockpile)
column3: Marked by dryness and some heat from alcohol, this wine also has a rich core of ripe cherries. It's very strong and powerful, not a Zinfandel that's shy or apologizes for its brashness. But that's the essence of Rockpile. Drink this sturdy wine now, and the ideal food pairing is barbecue.

column2: Zina Hyde Cunningham 2006 Merlot (Lake County)
column3: Although it's totally dry, this Merlot is a little too sharp, with a bite of acidity marring otherwise pleasant flavors of cherries, chocolate, mint and herbs. At its best now.

column2: Falcor 2005 Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: Rustic and somewhat sharp, this Zin has a green, spearmint streak, with some harsh tannins, which suggests unevenly ripened berries, despite very high alcohol. It's like a combination of cherry Lifesavers, blackberries and Altoids breath mints. Drink now.

column2: Arbios 2003 Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
column3: On a par with recent vintages, this four-year old Cab is soft and pleasant, with ripe cherry, blackberry, raspberry and herb flavors that are well oaked. The tannins are crunchy, but the wine isn't an ager. Best now through 2009.

column2: Joullian 2009 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Carmel Valley)
column3: Made in a style that's lower in alcohol and earthier than your typical Napa Valley Cabernet, this bottling has plenty of complex elegance. The blackberry, tobacco and cedar flavors will pair well with steak. Drink now–2017.

column2: Midnight 2010 Estate Merlot (Paso Robles)
column3: It's easy to drink this Merlot now for its soft, fat flavors. Cherries, red currants, pecan pie and smoky oak are rich on the palate. There's some spice on the finish, along with a little heat from alcohol.

column2: Sebastopol 2006 Three Blocks Syrah (Russian River Valley)
column3: Tastes a bit sweet and obvious now, with chocolate-covered cherry, blackberry jam, gingerbread cookie and smoke flavors. But it's pretty tannic, and well-balanced in acidity, so could develop bottle complexity down the road. Try after 2010.

column2: Shenanigans 2007 Fine Irish Cab Cabernet Sauvignon (Lodi)
column3: Starts off fine, with rich blackberry and black currant aromas and flavors. But once you take a sip, the wine turns sharp and unbalanced. Still, it's a perfectly decent sipper for everyday fare.

column2: Markham 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: There are solid Cabernet flavors of blackberries and black currants in this dry, tannic wine. It's rough and astringent in the mouth, without much charm, but a rich steak, maybe topped with a gorgonzola sauce, will make it shine.

column2: Markham 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: There are solid Cabernet flavors of blackberries and black currants in this dry, tannic wine. It's rough and astringent in the mouth, without much charm, but a rich steak, maybe topped with a gorgonzola sauce, will make it shine.

column2: Talisman 2004 Wildcat Mountain Vineyard Pinot Noir (Carneros)
column3: This is Steve MacRostie's vineyard, located in the far northwest of the appellation, practically in Sonoma Coast. Their '04 strikes me as a little heavy and obvious now, but that may be a function of its relative youth. The wine is dry and crisp, with jammy raspberry, cherry, cola and spice flavors. Could do interesting things in the next 3–5 years.

column2: Beaulieu Vineyard 2006 Reserve Pinot Noir (Carneros)
column3: With the '06 Reserve, Beaulieu has crafted a dry, herb-tinged Pinot of great style and sophistication. The cherry, cocoa and tobacco flavors are restrained by California standards, resulting in a wine whose structure stars. Should age, too. Best now through 2012.

column2: Kenwood 1998 Massara Merlot (Sonoma Valley)
column3: . Unfortunately, 1998 was not 1997, when this bottling was very good. This vintage is less ripe, and so the wine has some green aromas and flavors, in addition to  blackberry. That makes the tannins stick out more. There's nothing to contain them, but if you pair it with the right, rich foods, it will be just fine. —S.H.

column2: Wait Cellars 2009 Devoto Garden Vineyard Pinot Noir (Green Valley)
column3: This has flavors of cherry and blackberry jam, cola and spice. It's crisp in acidity and dry, as Pinot should be. This is direct and polished; it's not likely to get better with age, so drink now.

column2: Stolpman 2008 La Croce Red (Santa Ynez Valley)
column3: A rich, dramatic and impressive wine. With vital acidity and dryness, it has complex layers of ripe cherries, red licorice, cranberries, pomegranates, mocha and cinnamon. Falls somewhere in texture between Pinot Noir and Merlot, either of which it can substitute for. Drink now.

column2: Tudal 2009 Bacigalupi Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: The vineyard is in a warmer part of the valley, and the wine is a bit rustic, lacking some delicacy. But it has deeply delicious raspberry and cherry pie filling flavors, with earth and licorice notes elaborated by smoky oak. Give it a good, long decant.

column2: Sage Road 2010 Syrah (Arroyo Grande Valley)
column3: Tough, dry and gritty, this Syrah has stringy tannins and citrusy acids. Its austerity is relieved by the blackberry and black currant flavors. Pair this with rich, fatty meats and cheeses to help soften the mouthfeel.

column2: Concannon 2006 Selected Vineyards Syrah (Central Coast)
column3: A very nice buy at this price. Dry and jammy, the wine features ripe flavors of blackberries, cherries, anise, cocoa and mint, with smoky, oaky notes and mouthwateringly crisp coastal acidity.

column2: St. Supéry 2006 Elu Red (Napa Valley)
column3: Quite elegant, but not showing well given the price, being somewhat soft and direct in candied blackberries, cherries and chocolate-covered mint. The vintage was a difficult one for St. Supéry. The wine is lacks the stuffing for ageability. Drink now–2013.

column2: Roadhouse Winery 2008 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: A solid coastal Pinot. Shows lots of typicity in the dryness, crisp acidity and earthy, mushroomy flavors of cherries, and the way the tannins scour the palate. Drinks a bit hard now. Give it a year or two in the cellar.

column2: Daou 2011 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
column3: Ripe, soft and oaky, with gentle, sweet flavors of blackberry, blueberry and cherry jam, mocha and toast. Easy to drink now with a great grilled steak.

column2: Municipal Winemakers 2007 Best Barrel Cabernet Sauvignon (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)
column3: Tasted in the late summer of 2010, this Cab was pretty tannic and acidic, despite some very rich and dynamic blackberry, black cherry, currant and licorice flavors. It will hit its peak sometime in the next 2–3 years.

column2: Peachy Canyon 2007 Mustang Springs Zinfandel (Paso Robles)
column3: Spicy and dry, this Zin offers flavors of currants, tobacco, pepper and cocoa. The tannins are thick, but acidity is low, giving it a soft mouthfeel. Could be more concentrated, but it's an elegant wine.

column2: Babcock 2010 Microcosm Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
column3: Rich, dry and pretty full-bodied for a Pinot Noir, this is stuffed with flavors of cherry pie and cola, made brisk by acidity. A little heavy, but sound and complex.

column2: Martin Estate 2007 Collector's Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)
column3: A good 100% Cabernet, with complex, pleasant cherry, blackberry and oak flavors. Quite tannic now, with a sandpapery mouthfeel, and very full-bodied. Feels a little ponderous, but could be going through an awkward phase. Try again after 2013.

column2: Lake Sonoma 2006 Saini Farms Old Vine Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: Here's a good, rich, savory young Zin to get those tastebuds whistling. Clean acidity and smooth tannins frame Zinny flavors of wild berries, teriyaki and Asian spices. Drink now.

column2: Lake Sonoma 2006 Saini Farms Old Vine Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: Here's a good, rich, savory young Zin to get those tastebuds whistling. Clean acidity and smooth tannins frame Zinny flavors of wild berries, teriyaki and Asian spices. Drink now.

column2: Oakville Ranch 2005 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Very fruit-driven, this dry Cab has jammy cherry, blackberry and currant flavors, with a rich edge of cedar and cocoa. It's a bit immature now and should develop bottle complexities over the next 6–8 years.

column2: Greenwood Ridge 2008 Scherrer Vineyard Zinfandel (Sonoma County)
column3: Tastes jammy and sharp, like a barrel sample, with acidic flavors of raspberries, black cherries and spices. The tannins are rich and smooth. A very good wine, but bristly and tough in youth. Give it a few years to mellow.

column2: Millésimé 2010 Cabernet Franc (Santa Barbara County)
column3: This is a bone dry, tannic, rather austere wine. It has suggestions of cherry skins and red licorice, with brisk acidity. Not an ager, it needs rich, fatty meats and cheeses for balance.

column2: WillaKenzie Estate 2007 Gamay Noir (Willamette Valley)
column3: A delightful bottle, this fruit-packed Gamay has more stuffing and sweetness than most of the Oregon Pinots from 2007. Plums, cherries and black currants ramble through the mouth, running into some fairly stiff, chewy tannins. This is a sturdy, immediately drinkable, thoroughly enjoyable quaffer.

column2: Brander 2011 Sawyer Lindquist Vineyard Syrah (Edna Valley)
column3: So rich with cherries, red currants, bacon and pepper, this is a terrific wine to drink now. There's an edge of sweet, smoky oak that makes it particularly enticing, while that Edna Valley acidity is as brisk as can be.

column2: Kenwood 2010 Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)
column3: This is a pretty good Cabernet, showing some real fanciness, with soft tannins framing blackberry, currant, anise and herb flavors and a touch of sweet, smoky oak. Not an ager, so drink up.

column2: Morro Bay 2006 Split Oak Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (California)
column3: A nice Cabernet for this everyday price. Dry and smooth, it shows interesting flavors of black currants, plums, herbs and spice, with a touch of smoky oak.

column2: Provenance Vineyards 2009 Beckstoffer To Kalon Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)
column3: Fierce in tannins, with a sandpapery astringency, this wine has oak that sticks out with sweet, smoky toast. The blackberry and cassis flavors are ripe and pleasing. All the parts haven't come together, so your best bet is to stick it in the cellar and see what happens.

column2: Cameron Hughes 2007 Lot 172 Cabernet Sauvignon (Atlas Peak)
column3: Another of Cameron Hughes' terrific Cabernets at a good price. This wine will easily stand beside Cabs far more expensive, with its dry, crisply complex flavors of blackberries, cherries, currants, anise, mocha and oak.

column2: Desmond 2008 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Some bottle age shows on this soft, gentle Pinot Noir. It's tasty in raspberries and cherries, with a rich spiciness and a smoky coat of oak. Seems at its best now, so drink up.

column2: Steltzner 2008 Claret Red (Napa Valley)
column3: Dry and brittle, with some sharp tannic edges. Yet it's good and ripe in blackberries, cherries, currants and cedar. Decent price for a Napa Cab.

column2: Highlands 2006 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)
column3: Compared to Highlands' regular Cab, this is a great example of sometimes, more is less. The '06 Reserve is a gigantic wine, both in ripely extracted currants and in the taste of new, smoky oak. But it's very size makes it ponderous. The question is one of ageability. It could well be a sleeper. Try beyond 2010.

column2: Angeline 2006 Pinot Noir (Sonoma County)
column3: A little one-dimensional, but pleasant enough, with silky flavors of cola, licorice, cherries and smoky oak. This is one of the better Pinot Noirs in this price range.

column2: Mueller 2006 Block Eleven Syrah (Russian River Valley)
column3: At more than four years of age, this Syrah is very dry. It's also tannic, with a hard, astringent bite to the blackberries. Somewhat rustic, it seems unlikely to develop in the bottle.

column2: Rutherford Ranch 2005 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: A little sharp, but easily the winery's best non-vineyard designated Cab since the '02. Shows a ripeness level that slam dunks cherries, blackberries, cola and oak onto the palate, yet maintains an elegant dryness.

column2: Turn Four 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: A good Cab, chockful of grilled blackberry, cassis, cocoa and sweet smoky oak flavors that finish rich and spicy. Has some real elegance, at an affordable price.

column2: J. Lohr 2010 Seven Oaks Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
column3: A polished Cabernet from a winery that knows how to produce super-drinkable Cabs at affordable prices. It's stylishly dry, with oak-infused blackberry jam, currant and mocha flavors. Shows a deliciousness factor that makes the price a real bargain.

column2: Bianchi 2007 Signature Selection Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
column3: A really nice Cabernet that shows how well Paso Robles can produce this kind of wine while keeping prices modest. Made from 100% of the variety, it's dry and rich in tannins, with interesting flavors of blackberries, currants, anise and smoky oak. Drink now.

column2: Venteux 2010 Estate Grown Syrah (Paso Robles)
column3: This is an enormously rich, extracted wine, that's vast in cherries, blackberries, currants, chocolate and oak flavors. Yet it has balancing acidity and tannins. Best now and over the next few years, especially a great barbecued steak or leg of lamb.

column2: Calera 2005 Ryan Vineyard Pinot Noir (Mount Harlan)
column3: This isn't the best Ryan Calera has produced over the years. The wine is a little sweet and direct in cherry, raspberry, currant and cola flavors, and while the acids and tannins are just fine, it doesn't seem like it's going anywhere. Drink now.

column2: Redtree 2009 Pinot Noir (California)
column3: Good price for an everyday Pinot Noir. It's not particularly complex, but shows a nice, silky texture, with good acidity and firm dryness. The flavors are of cherries and oak.

column2: Simi 2004 Landslide Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
column3: When this hilly vineyard Cab first came out, it was very good, but quality has slipped over the years. The '04 is perfectly decent in oak-infused blackberry and currant flavors and rich tannins, and it may even improve for a few years.

column2: Salvatore Principe 2007 Running with the Bulls Cabernet Sauvignon (North Coast)
column3: Nice and dry, with good varietal flavors of blackberries and currants, wrapped into rich tannins. It's a fine Cabernet to drink with ordinary food, and a good value.

column2: La Fenêtre 2006 Santa Barbara Highlands Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Barbara County)
column3: The winery continues to try to figure out how to grow Cabernet in this remote part of the county. Ripeness isn't the problem. Structure is. The flavors are upfront in blackberries, cherries and currants, but complexity and dryness remain challenges.

column2: Madorom 2009 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Tastes unusually lush and soft for a Napa Cab. While it's officially dry, sweet, caramelized oak and raspberry-jam flavors, along with a slick, glycerine mouthfeel, makes it as rich as a candy bar.

column2: Snowden 2007 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Soft and gentle in structure, this Cab appeals for its ripe, pie-filling flavors of blackberries, cherries and spices. It's a pretty, polished young wine whose vigorous tannins give it a sandpapery texture. Ready now.

column2: Blackbird Vineyards 2008 Contrarian Red (Oak Knoll District)
column3: Lots of ripe blackberry, cherry, currant, licorice and cedar flavors in this dry, tannic wine. It's a little rude in texture, with a jagged mouthfeel that could age out, but you never know. Give it a good long decant before serving.

column2: De Loach 2008 Cool Coastal Vineyards Pinot Noir (Central Coast)
column3: Quite sharp in acidity, giving a bite of tartness to the dry flavors of cola, cherries, sandalwood and pepper. A good, silky Pinot for drinking now.

column2: La Crema 2012 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Call this Pinot useful, rather than complex or ageable. It's nicely dry, acidic and silky in the mouth, with jammy raspberry, cherry and persimmon flavors. Food pairings range from steak to tuna tartare or a bacon burger.

column2: Bigvine 2006 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Here's a sound, everyday-style Cabernet for drinking now. It's dry and tannic, with rich flavors of blackberries, black currants and plums, enhanced with sweet, smoky oak.

column2: Big Vine 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Very soft and melted, lacking structure, although the flavors are enormous. They're explosive in blackberries, chocolate, anise and smoky cedar. Despite the flaws, this is a fairly impressive Napa Cabernet for the price.

column2: Rancho Zabaco 2005 Sonoma Heritage Vines Zinfandel (Sonoma County)
column3: Gallo did a great job with this wine, producing 31,000 cases and yet making the wine smooth, balanced and delicious. It's quintessential Sonoma Zin, with briary flavors of wild cherries and raspberries, and coatings of chocolate, anisette, bacon and spices.

column2: Pedroncelli 2008 Bench Vineyards Merlot (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: A terrific Merlot, especially at this price. Impresses for its soft lushness and intricate flavors of berries, currants, cola, anise, pepper and sandalwood. A real bargain. Production was 2,500 cases. Drink soon.

column2: Schug 2008 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: Sharp in acidity and bone dry, this is a good, everyday Pinot Noir. It shows a properly silky texture, and flavors of cola, cherries, red currants and cedar. Drink now.

column2: Rubicon Estate 2005 Cask Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Lots of new, smoky oak stands out on this polished Cab. Give it a little time in a decanter before you drink, as it pulls together, becoming more powerful and accenting the blackberry and cherry flavors. Should develop for a decade.

column2: Barlow 2009 Unfiltered Merlot (Calistoga)
column3: Softly delicious, this is a beautiful Merlot to drink now. It's a little hot in alcohol on the finish, but feels elegant in the mouth, offering waves of cherries, currants and mocha.

column2: Barlow 2009 Unfiltered Merlot (Calistoga)
column3: Softly delicious, this is a beautiful Merlot to drink now. It's a little hot in alcohol on the finish, but feels elegant in the mouth, offering waves of cherries, currants and mocha.

column2: Lake Sonoma 2010 Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
column3: Soft and one-dimensional but interesting, this Cabernet has upfront flavors of blackberry jam, black currants, anise and oak. It's dry and tannic, but doesn't have the stuffing to age. Drink now–2016.

column2: De Loach 2008 Thornton Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)
column3: Soft and appealing, this Pinot offers lush, elaborate flavors of raspberry and cherry pie filling, mocha and sandalwood flavors, finished with sweet, dusty Indian spices. It's made for drinking now.

column2: Tudal 2005 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: An elegant Cabernet that's ready to drink tonight and will hold for some years. Shows good Napa character, with lush, ripe tannins and flavors of black currants, blackberries and cedar that cry out for a good steak.

column2: Jekel 2008 Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)
column3: Don't discount this Pinot Noir because it's in a screw top and the price is under $20. It's quite a nice wine, dry and silky. Made in a lighter style to be opened now, it has pleasant cherry, cola and sandalwood flavors.

column2: Beaulieu Vineyard 2011 Coastal Estates Merlot (California)
column3: A little one-dimensional, but offers enough cherry, red currant and smoky oak flavors to get by for everyday eating. A good example of the art of blending, with 115,000 cases produced.
