column2: Cameron Hughes 2007 Lot 287 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Lots of rich blackberries, cherries and chocolate in this Cab, but it's no mere fruit bomb. It's saved by a fine structure of acids and tannins. Very nice price for a wine this good.

column2: Thomas George 2007 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Nice and silky, and velvety smooth in the mouth, this Pinot offers complex flavors of cherries, raspberries, cola, mocha and sandalwood. Easy to like for its richness and spicy finish. Ready now.

column2: Pali 2007 Turner Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
column3: Great now with lamb, this Pinot is softly complex and forward in fruit, with a silky texture. It shows cherry, raspberry, mocha, anise and smoky oak flavors. Best now and for a few more years.

column2: Palmaz 2005 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Deliciously drinkable now, with very dry but ripely opulent flavors of black currants, cherry marmalade, mocha, root beer and caramelized oak. Could have greater structure and a longer finish, but lovely with a charbroiled steak.

column2: Pali 2008 Keefer Ranch Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Too acidic and tart in wintergreen flavors, a real disappointment from this well-regarded vineyard. On the plus side, it's bone dry and silky, and shows cherry and cola flavors accented with sweet, smoky oak. Ready to drink now.

column2: Larry Hyde and Sons 2009 Pinot Noir (Carneros)
column3: The grapes come from just south of the Carneros Highway, on the Napa side. It's a big, somewhat alcoholic Pinot, rich in spicy cherries, raspberries, mocha and sandalwood. A flamboyant, luscious wine.

column2: Brazin Cellars 2007 Old Vine Zinfandel (Lodi)
column3: Peppery and hot, almost Porty, with rich flavors of blackberries, cherries, chocolate, bacon and sandalwood. With smooth tannins, it turns soft and spicy on the finish.

column2: Halleck 2008 Hallberg Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: Tasting rich and vital, this has a wealth of raspberry, cherry and cola flavors to the long, spicy finish. It's just what you want Pinot Noir to be: dry, silky and elegant. It doesn't seem to be an ager, so drink by 2014.

column2: Patland 2010 Stagecoach Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Stagecoach Cabs are always impressive for their power and depth, but this one seems like Stagecoach on steroids. It's insanely rich and extracted with blackberry and cherry jam flavors, along with plenty of sweet oak. It's so rich, it could use 7–8 years to calm down.

column2: Stryker Sonoma 2010 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
column3: It's a clash of the titans now, with massively ripe blackberry, currant and chocolate flavors battling a battalion of oak and tannins for supremecy. It's a good wine—rich and soft in the Alexander Valley way—but unresolved. Try giving it 4–5 years in the cellar.

column2: Écluse 2010 Lock Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
column3: California Cabernet simply doesn't get richer or riper than this. It explodes with blackberry and cherry jam and chocolate flavors whose sweetness persists into the long, spicy finish. And yet the wine is technically dry. Drink over the next few years.

column2: Peju 2008 Merlot (Napa Valley)
column3: Peju's Merlots have been inconsistent. When they're good, they're quite good, but you never know. This 2008, from a less successful vintage, is all right. It's dry and tannic and soft in cherry and tobacco flavors. But there's not a lot going on. Drink up.

column2: Peju 2008 Merlot (Napa Valley)
column3: Peju's Merlots have been inconsistent. When they're good, they're quite good, but you never know. This 2008, from a less successful vintage, is all right. It's dry and tannic and soft in cherry and tobacco flavors. But there's not a lot going on. Drink up.

column2: Kynsi 2006 Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)
column3: A cheerful Pinot Noir, rich and silky, and perfect for drinking now with lamb chops, steak or grilled salmon. It's dry and crisp, with good flavors of cherries, spices and sandalwood.

column2: Souverain 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)
column3: Nice Cabernet flavors in this dry, softly appealing wine. Satisfies with waves of blackberries and black currants, touched with oak. Drink now, and easy to find, with 38,000 cases produced.

column2: Perry Creek 2007 Zinman Zinfandel (El Dorado)
column3: A lovely Zinfandel, soft and dry, with luscious cherry, raspberry and sandalwood flavors, dusted with pepper and cocoa. Easy to drink and versatile with everything from pizza to a grilled steak.

column2: Clos du Lac 2004 Reserve Blend Zinfandel (Sierra Foothills)
column3: A few words that describe this wine are lusty, brawny, rustic, really ripe, jammy, peppery, smooth and spicy. In other words, classic Foothills Zin. But just as important is what it's not. It's not high in alcohol, nor is it sweet. Drink this balanced Zin with barbecued ribs.

column2: Babcock 2009 Precocious Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)
column3: From the Los Alamos Valley, an oaky, mushroomy Pinot Noir, with blackberry, raspberry and cherry pie filling flavors as well as earthy notes of mushrooms and cola. Voluptuous and silky, it's lovely for drinking now.

column2: Wine Spots 2006 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: A good, everyday Cabernet. It's a bit gritty and hard in tannins, but very dry, with fine classic flavors of blackberries, black currants and oak. Give it a brief decant before drinking.

column2: Summers 2009 Four-Acre Zinfandel (Calistoga)
column3: Rich, blood warming and heady, this has vast and complex flavors of blackberry jam, licorice, bacon, spice and sweet, smoky sandalwood. It's hard to imagine a better wine to drink with barbecue.

column2: Opaque 2007 Petit Verdot (Paso Robles)
column3: Lots of everything in this wine. Tannins, fruit, oak, acids, minerals, you name it. The result is very rich, but the astringent tannins overwhelm, and will never age out.

column2: B.R. Cohn 2010 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)
column3: This is the winery's best Pinot since 2007, although it does seem to be peaking. The raspberry, cherry, cola and sandalwood flavors are housed in a tart, silky texture. Grilled tuna strongly suggests itself.

column2: Baldacci 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)
column3: Tough in tannins, with an astringent, lockdown quality. That's the iron fist of this wine. The velvet glove is the rich, flamboyant core of blackberries and cassis. Give this young wine at least six years to come around.

column2: Baldacci 2007 Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)
column3: Tough in tannins, with an astringent, lockdown quality. That's the iron fist of this wine. The velvet glove is the rich, flamboyant core of blackberries and cassis. Give this young wine at least six years to come around.

column2: Whitcraft 2012 Pence Ranch Swan Selection Pinot Noir (Santa Ynez Valley)
column3: This is a severe Pinot Noir, dry and acidic and unflattering to the palate. There are some good, complex cherry, currant, tea and spice flavors, but they're hard to appreciate because the wine is so tannic. It does not seem like a cellar candidate.

column2: Due Cani 2009 La Encantada Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)
column3: This wine, even at the age of four-plus years, remains dry, tannic and acidic. It has modest raspberry and cherry jam fruit, but isn't going anywhere.

column2: Villa Mt. Eden 2006 Grand Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Shows enough fanciness to make it worth the price. Although it has no possibilities of improving with age, it's a fine, softly gentle Cabernet to drink now. Shows correct blackberry, black currant and oak flavors.

column2: Sixteen by Twenty 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Lush and ripe, made in the modern California cult style of flamboyantly sweet blackberries, cassis and chocolate, soft tannins and immediate appeal. Defines richness and opulence, if not complexity. Drink now–2014.

column2: Vellum 2009 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Lots of characteristic Cabernet flavor in this wine. Blackberrry jam and cassis liqueur flavors flood the mouth, heady and flashy and long in the finish. The tannins are thick, yet so soft, you can enjoy this wine now, although it will develop over the next ten years.

column2: Vellum 2009 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: Lots of characteristic Cabernet flavor in this wine. Blackberrry jam and cassis liqueur flavors flood the mouth, heady and flashy and long in the finish. The tannins are thick, yet so soft, you can enjoy this wine now, although it will develop over the next ten years.

column2: Babcock 2009 The Loin Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Ynez Valley)
column3: There are good, dry flavors in this Cabernet. It's a little on the coarse side, but shows lots of extraction to the blackberries and black currants. The tannins are hard and firm, and not likely to age out, so drink up.

column2: Sterling 2005 Reserve Merlot (Napa Valley)
column3: The best Sterling reserve Merlots are ageworthy. The others are merely tannic. This '05 straddles the line. It's certainly a dry, tannicly astringent wine that shuts down the palate. But you'll find some rich black cherry and currant flavors. Roll the dice and give it through 2010 to come around.

column2: Bentley 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)
column3: Soft, smooth and delicious, this offers a beautiful example of the modern cult style of flashy drinkability. It tastes expensive, with refined tannins and ripe blackberry, cassis and oak flavors. This could be an ager. From Laura Zahtila.

column2: Fernwood 2007 Estate Grown Redwood Retreat Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Cruz Mountains)
column3: You'll find thick tannins and soft acidity in this wine, which offers direct, jammy blackberry and cassis flavors. It's quite a rich wine that seems best now and for the next few years.

column2: Fernwood 2007 Estate Grown Redwood Retreat Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Cruz Mountains)
column3: You'll find thick tannins and soft acidity in this wine, which offers direct, jammy blackberry and cassis flavors. It's quite a rich wine that seems best now and for the next few years.

column2: Robert Mondavi 2006 Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)
column3: Shows everything that's noble about Oakville, from the wonderful, dusty tannins to the dryness and overall balance. Lovely, with flavors of blackberries, black currants and cedar. Could have more depth, though.

column2: Proulx 2010 Swiss Colina Zinfandel (Paso Robles)
column3: This is a big, rich, ripe Zinfandel that tastes hotter and headier than its official alcohol reading of 14.6% abv. It's sweet with black cherry jam and raisins, with a chocolatey finish. Not for everyone, but a good example of the ripe Paso Robles style.

column2: Martin Ray 2011 Reserve Merlot (Oak Knoll District)
column3: This is a delicious Merlot for drinking now. It's Martin Ray's best in years, a dry, smooth, soft wine, with elaborate cherry pie, blackberry jam and oak flavors that are complex and spicy.

column2: Simple Math Cellars 2008 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)
column3: A lighter, more elegant style of Cabernet, dry and classy. Likeable for its balance of acids, tannins, alcohol and oak, and rich blackberry, cassis and cedar flavors. Drink now.

column2: Chelsea Goldschmidt 2009 Merlot (Dry Creek Valley)
column3: Great price on a Merlot this good. Most others would charge $25 or more, but Goldschmidt has held the line. It appeals for the soft tannins and easy flavors of raspberries, cherries, cocoa and sweet, smoky oak. Drink now.

column2: Chimney Rock 2006 Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)
column3: You'll want to give this young Cab some time in the cellar, because it's locked down in tannins. Buried underneath the astringency is a wealth of sweet black currants and savory anise and sandalwood. Try after 2011.

column2: JR Wine 2005 Cork Tree Vineyard Merlot (Napa Valley)
column3: A polished, elegant Merlot, with good structure framing deep flavors of currants, carob, violets and anise. The thick tannins suggest a good steak. Now through 2009.

column2: Cameron Hughes 2010 Lot 360 Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)
column3: This is an impressive young Cabernet: It's bone dry, tannic and intense, with flavors of mountain blackberries and black currants. It may even age for a few years.

column2: Ventana 1999 Syrah (Arroyo Seco)
column3: You want to like this wine more than you do, because it's from a great vineyard and a great vintage. The problem is thinness. It's got great bones, superb texture and dry tannins, and it's easy to taste the quality of the blackberry, pepper-infused fruit because it flatters the palate. But everything is diluted. —S.H.

column2: Envy 2007 Envy Estate Vineyard Petite Sirah (Napa Valley)
column3: Very ripe, to the point of overripe. The blackberries and black currants veer into raisins, and there's a hint of raisinskin tartness that, combined with the strong tannins, adds to the tough mouthfeel. Will probably soften with age, without necessarily gaining complexity.

column2: Aril 2009 Syrah (Napa Valley)
column3: This is a lovely, gentle Syrah for drinking now with upscale fare. It's soft in both tannins and acids, making it velvety in the mouth, and the blackberry, cassis and mocha flavors are, in a word, delicious.

column2: Peloton 2011 Lunacy Ranch Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)
column3: Ripe blackberry, cherry and toasty oak flavors mark this Cab. It's soft in acids and tannins and high in alcohol, which gives it a glyceriney sweetness on the finish. Drink up.
